js-snippet-clipboard-copy-unpositioned DirectoryRichtextContent-module__SharedMarkdownContent--BTKsc" data-hpc="true"><article class="markdown-body entry-content container-lg" itemprop="text"><p dir="auto">Lightweight, zero-dependency library for validating arbitrary runtime data in TypeScript. <code>valleys</code> provides assertion-based validation that refines your types in-place — no cloning, no transformations, and minimal runtime overhead.</p>
<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Installation</h3><a id="user-content-installation" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: Installation" href="#installation"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div>
<div class="highlight highlight-source-shell notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="npm install valleys"><pre>npm install valleys</pre></div>
<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h2 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Quick Start</h2><a id="user-content-quick-start" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: Quick Start" href="#quick-start"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div>
<p dir="auto"><code>valleys</code> validates your data and narrows its type in-place. Your original values remain unchanged - only their TypeScript types are refined. The <code>validate</code> function runs a runtime check and, on success, asserts the original variable's type. On failure, it throws a
<code>ValidationError</code>.</p>
<div class="highlight highlight-source-ts notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="import { object, string, number, validate } from "valleys";

// Example of untrusted data (e.g., from an API)
const input: unknown = { id: 123, name: "Alice" };

// Validate the data (throws if validation fails)
validate(input, object({ id: number(), name: string() }));

// `input` is now typed as { id: number; name: string }
console.log(input.id, input.name);"><pre><span class="pl-k">import</span> <span class="pl-kos">{</span> <span class="pl-s1">object</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-s1">string</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-s1">number</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-s1">validate</span> <span class="pl-kos">}</span> <span class="pl-k">from</span> <span class="pl-s">"valleys"</span><span class="pl-kos">;</span>

<span class="pl-c">// Example of untrusted data (e.g., from an API)</span>
<span class="pl-k">const</span> <span class="pl-s1">input</span>: <span class="pl-smi">unknown</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-kos">{</span> <span class="pl-c1">id</span>: <span class="pl-c1">123</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-c1">name</span>: <span class="pl-s">"Alice"</span> <span class="pl-kos">}</span><span class="pl-kos">;</span>

<span class="pl-c">// Validate the data (throws if validation fails)</span>
<span class="pl-en">validate</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s1">input</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-en">object</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-kos">{</span> <span class="pl-c1">id</span>: <span class="pl-en">number</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-c1">name</span>: <span class="pl-en">string</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span> <span class="pl-kos">}</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span><span class="pl-kos">;</span>

<span class="pl-c">// `input` is now typed as { id: number; name: string }</span>
<span class="pl-smi">console</span><span class="pl-kos">.</span><span class="pl-en">log</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s1">input</span><span class="pl-kos">.</span><span class="pl-c1">id</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-s1">input</span><span class="pl-kos">.</span><span class="pl-c1">name</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span><span class="pl-kos">;</span></pre></div>
<p dir="auto">Libraries like <a href="https://zod.dev/" rel="nofollow">Zod</a>, <a href="https://valibot.dev/" rel="nofollow">Valibot</a>, <a href="https://decoders.cc/" rel="nofollow">Decoders</a>, etc typically return a new (often transformed) value from <code>.parse()</code>. <code>valleys</code> instead asserts types directly - this provides several performance benefits as no time is spent copying arrays, strings or nested objects. This makes <code>valleys</code> ideal for performance-critical applications where memory efficiency and speed matter.</p>
<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Error handling</h3><a id="user-content-error-handling" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: Error handling" href="#error-handling"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div>
<p dir="auto"><code>valleys</code> uses a fail-fast approach - validation stops and throws an error immediately when the first validation failure is encountered. This provides better performance and clearer error messages by focusing on the first issue found. The <code>validate</code> function throws a <code>ValidationError</code> if validation fails. This error object includes the path to the exact location of the validation failure (e.g., nested objects/arrays), the expected schema and ruleset that the value failed to match. Additionally, the error includes a pre-formatted human-readable error message.</p>
<p dir="auto">Example error message:</p>
<div class="snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="Validation failed at user.age due to schema mismatch; expected schema: {"type":"number"}"><pre class="notranslate"><code>Validation failed at user.age due to schema mismatch; expected schema: {"type":"number"}
</code></pre></div>
<p dir="auto">For more control over error messages, you can catch <code>ValidationError</code> and traverse its <code>path</code> property to build custom messages.</p>
<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">API Reference</h3><a id="user-content-api-reference" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: API Reference" href="#api-reference"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div>
<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h4 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto"><code>string()</code></h4><a id="user-content-string" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: string()" href="#string"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div>
<p dir="auto">Validates that a value is a string. Optionally accepts rules for validation.</p>
<div class="highlight highlight-source-ts notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="import { string, validate } from "valleys";

// Basic usage
validate(input, string());
// input is typed as string

// With rules
validate(input, string({ minLength: 3, maxLength: 50 }));"><pre><span class="pl-k">import</span> <span class="pl-kos">{</span> <span class="pl-s1">string</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-s1">validate</span> <span class="pl-kos">}</span> <span class="pl-k">from</span> <span class="pl-s">"valleys"</span><span class="pl-kos">;</span>

<span class="pl-c">// Basic usage</span>
<span class="pl-en">validate</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s1">input</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-en">string</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span><span class="pl-kos">;</span>
<span class="pl-c">// input is typed as string</span>

<span class="pl-c">// With rules</span>
<span class="pl-en">validate</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s1">input</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-en">string</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-kos">{</span> <span class="pl-c1">minLength</span>: <span class="pl-c1">3</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-c1">maxLength</span>: <span class="pl-c1">50</span> <span class="pl-kos">}</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span><span class="pl-kos">;</span></pre></div>
<p dir="auto"><strong>Rules:</strong></p>
<ul dir="auto">

<span class="pl-en">validate</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s1">input</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-en">object</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-kos">{</span> <span class="pl-c1">id</span>: <span class="pl-en">number</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-c1">name</span>: <span class="pl-en">string</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-c1">active</span>: <span class="pl-en">boolean</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span> <span class="pl-kos">}</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span><span class="pl-kos">;</span>
<span class="pl-c">// input is typed as { id: number; name: string; active: boolean }</span>

<span class="pl-c">// Nested objects</span>
<span class="pl-en">validate</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span>
  <span class="pl-s1">input</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span>
  <span class="pl-en">object</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-kos">{</span>
    <span class="pl-c1">user</span>: <span class="pl-en">object</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-kos">{</span>
      <span class="pl-c1">id</span>: <span class="pl-en">number</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span>
      <span class="pl-c1">profile</span>: <span class="pl-en">object</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-kos">{</span> <span class="pl-c1">name</span>: <span class="pl-en">string</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-c1">age</span>: <span class="pl-en">number</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span> <span class="pl-kos">}</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span>
    <span class="pl-kos">}</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span>
  <span class="pl-kos">}</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span>
<span class="pl-kos">)</span><span class="pl-kos">;</span></pre></div>
<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h4 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto"><code>or()</code></h4><a id="user-content-or" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: or()" href="#or"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div>
<p dir="auto">Creates a union type validator that accepts any of the provided validators.</p>
<div class="highlight highlight-source-ts notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="import { or, string, number, null_, validate } from "valleys";

// String or number
validate(input, or([string(), number()]));
// input is typed as string | number

// Nullable string (string or null)
validate(input, or([string(), null_()]));
// input is typed as string | null

// Multiple types
validate(
  input,
  or([constant("pending"), constant("active"), constant("completed")])
);
// input is typed as "pending" | "active" | "completed""><pre><span class="pl-k">import</span> <span class="pl-kos">{</span> <span class="pl-s1">or</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-s1">string</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-s1">number</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-s1">null_</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-s1">validate</span> <span class="pl-kos">}</span> <span class="pl-k">from</span> <span class="pl-s">"valleys"</span><span class="pl-kos">;</span>

<span class="pl-c">// String or number</span>
<span class="pl-en">validate</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s1">input</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-en">or</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-kos">[</span><span class="pl-en">string</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-en">number</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span><span class="pl-kos">]</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span><span class="pl-kos">;</span>
<span class="pl-c">// input is typed as string | number</span>

<span class="pl-c">// Nullable string (string or null)</span>
<span class="pl-en">validate</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s1">input</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-en">or</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-kos">[</span><span class="pl-en">string</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-en">null_</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span><span class="pl-kos">]</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span><span class="pl-kos">;</span>
<span class="pl-c">// input is typed as string | null</span>

<span class="pl-c">// Multiple types</span>
<span class="pl-en">validate</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span>
  <span class="pl-s1">input</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span>
  <span class="pl-en">or</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-kos">[</span><span class="pl-en">constant</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s">"pending"</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-en">constant</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s">"active"</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-en">constant</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-s">"completed"</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span><span class="pl-kos">]</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span>
<span class="pl-kos">)</span><span class="pl-kos">;</span>
<span class="pl-c">// input is typed as "pending" | "active" | "completed"</span></pre></div>

<p dir="auto">A type utility that extracts the output type from a validator. Useful when you need to reference the type that a validaator validates.</p>
<div class="highlight highlight-source-ts notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="import { object, string, number, InferOutputOf } from "valleys";

const userValidator = object({ id: number(), name: string() });
type User = InferOutputOf<typeof userValidator>;
// User is { id: number; name: string }"><pre><span class="pl-k">import</span> <span class="pl-kos">{</span> <span class="pl-s1">object</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-s1">string</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-s1">number</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-v">InferOutputOf</span> <span class="pl-kos">}</span> <span class="pl-k">from</span> <span class="pl-s">"valleys"</span><span class="pl-kos">;</span>

<span class="pl-k">const</span> <span class="pl-s1">userValidator</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-en">object</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-kos">{</span> <span class="pl-c1">id</span>: <span class="pl-en">number</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span><span class="pl-kos">,</span> <span class="pl-c1">name</span>: <span class="pl-en">string</span><span class="pl-kos">(</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span> <span class="pl-kos">}</span><span class="pl-kos">)</span><span class="pl-kos">;</span>
<span class="pl-k">type</span> <span class="pl-smi">User</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-smi">InferOutputOf</span><span class="pl-c1"><</span><span class="pl-k">typeof</span> <span class="pl-s1">userValidator</span><span class="pl-c1">></span><span class="pl-kos">;</span>

<section class='outer mha js-router-anchors outer--content'>
    <div class='flex-auto mha container--xs '>
                <div class='post__content__section wysiwyg p theme__anchors--underline' data-role='selectable'>
            <div class='post__content wysiwyg p theme__anchors--underline '>
    <p>Imagine that someone gives you a list of five numbers: 1, 6, 21, 107 and — wait for it — 47,176,870. Can you guess what comes next?</p>
<p>If you’re stumped, you’re not alone. These are the first five busy beaver numbers. They form a sequence that’s intimately tied to one of the most notoriously difficult questions in theoretical computer science. Determining the values of busy beaver numbers is a daunting challenge that has attracted a cult following among both professional and amateur mathematicians for over 60 years.</p>
<p>Researchers identified the first four busy beaver numbers in the 1960s and 1970s. The conspicuously larger fifth number, called BB(5), was only <a href="https://www.quantamagazine.org/amateur-mathematicians-find-fifth-busy-beaver-turing-machine-20240702/">definitively pinned down last year</a>, by a team made up mostly of amateur mathematicians working together in an online community called the <a href="https://bbchallenge.org/">Busy Beaver Challenge</a>.</p>
<p>No one knows how big BB(6) is. All we have are lower limits — truly staggering ones. In 2022 busy beaver hunters established that BB(6) must be, at a minimum, so large that it’s literally impossible to write down in ordinary decimal notation. Even if you somehow carved a digit into every atom in the cosmos, you’d run out of atoms before making any measurable progress.</p>
<p>“It’s way beyond anything that we could ever grasp or get our hands on,” said <a href="https://www.cs.utexas.edu/people/faculty-researchers/scott-aaronson">Scott Aaronson</a>, a computer scientist at the University of Texas, Austin.</p>
<p>Busy beaver hunters have <a href="https://wiki.bbchallenge.org/wiki/TMBR:_July_2025">now discovered</a> that this stupefyingly big number must be even bigger. The finding comes from one of the most mysterious and prolific contributors to the Busy Beaver Challenge, who proved a new lower limit on BB(6) in June and broke the record again a mere nine days later. The new results make the 2022 lower bound look positively puny.</p>
<p>“I keep on being surprised,” said <a href="https://www.cs.umd.edu/people/gasarch">William Gasarch</a>, a computer scientist at the University of Maryland. “Six is getting us into the stratosphere of large numbers.”</p>
<h2><strong>Beaver Trap</strong></h2>
<p>The notoriously difficult question behind the busy beaver numbers is this: Given the code of a computer program, can you tell whether it will eventually stop or run forever?</p>
<p>In 1936, the pioneering logician Alan Turing proved that there’s no universal procedure for answering this question, which became known as the halting problem. Any method that works for some programs will fail for others, and in some cases, no method will work.</p>
<p>Turing proved this seminal result by inventing a formal mathematical model of computation in which programs are represented by hypothetical devices now called <a href="https://www.quantamagazine.org/alan-turings-most-important-machine-was-never-built-20230503/">Turing machines</a>. Each Turing machine performs computations in discrete steps according to a unique list of simple rules. The more rules a Turing machine has, the more complex its behavior can get, and the harder it can be to determine whether it will halt.</p>
</div>
        </div>
    </div>

    <figure class='leading-0 w-full my-0 mx-auto flex items-center justify-center flex-col max-w-img-inline py-0 px-16 s:px-0 l:px-16  '>
        <div class='w-full flex justify-center max-w-mod-inline image--module s:flex-col s:m-auto'>
                            <div class='w-auto mr-2 last:mr-0 s:m-0 s:flex s:flex-col flex-1 s:px-5'>
                    <img src="https://www.quantamagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/HowTuringMachinesWork-cr.KristinaArmitage-Mobile.V2.svg" class="w-full m:hidden l:hidden mb-6 w-full s:mb-4" alt="A graphic explaining how turing machines work" decoding="async" /><img src="https://www.quantamagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/HowTuringMachinesWork-cr.KristinaArmitage-Desktop.V2.svg" class="mb-6 w-full s:mb-4 s:hidden" alt="A graphic explaining how turing machines work" decoding="async" />                </div>
                        </div>
        <figcaption class='block my-0 mx-auto  w-full'>
    <section class='s:pt-0 s:px-5 s:pb-6 s:w-full-minus-25'>
        <div class='w-full my-0 mx-auto max-w-mod-inline s:mt-4 s:mb-4'>
            <div class='attribution theme__anchors--solid wysiwyg pangram h6 mb1 fill-h '>
    <p>Kristina Armitage/<em>Quanta Magazine</em></p>
</div>
        </div>
    </section>
</figcaption>
    </figure>
<div class='acf-content scale1 mt2'>
    <section class='outer mha js-router-anchors outer--content'>
    <div class='flex-auto mha container--xs '>
                <div class='post__content__section wysiwyg p theme__anchors--underline' data-role='selectable'>
            <div class='post__content wysiwyg p theme__anchors--underline '>
    <p>But just how much harder? In 1962, the mathematician Tibor Radó invented a new way to explore this question through what he called <a href="https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1002/j.1538-7305.1962.tb00480.x">the busy beaver game</a>. To play, start by choosing a specific number of rules — call that number <em>n</em>. Your goal is to find the <em>n</em>-rule Turing machine that runs the longest before eventually halting. This machine is called the busy beaver, and the corresponding busy beaver number, BB(<em>n</em>), is the number of steps that it takes.</p>
<p>In principle, if you want to find the busy beaver for any given <em>n</em>, you just need to do a few things. First, list out all the possible <em>n</em>-rule Turing machines. Next, use a computer program to simulate running each machine. Look for telltale signs that machines will never halt — for example, many machines will fall into infinite repeating loops. Discard all these non-halting machines. Finally, record how many steps every other machine took before halting. The one with the longest runtime is your busy beaver.</p>
<p>In practice, this gets tricky. For starters, the number of possible machines grows rapidly with each new rule. Analyzing them all individually would be hopeless, so you’ll need to write a custom computer program to classify and discard machines. Some machines are easy to classify: They either halt quickly or fall into easily identifiable infinite loops. But others run for a long time without displaying any obvious pattern. For these machines, the halting problem deserves its fearsome reputation.</p>
<p>The more rules you add, the more computing power you need. But brute force isn’t enough. Some machines run for so long before halting that simulating them step by step is impossible. You need clever mathematical tricks to measure their runtimes.</p>
<p>“Technology improvements definitely help,” said <a href="https://www.sligocki.com/about/">Shawn Ligocki</a>, a software engineer and longtime busy beaver hunter. “But they only help so far.”</p>
<h2><strong>End of an Era</strong></h2>
<p>Busy beaver hunters started chipping away at the BB(6) problem in earnest in the 1990s and 2000s, during an impasse in the BB(5) hunt. Among them were Shawn Ligocki and his father, Terry, an applied mathematician who ran their search program in the off hours on powerful computers at Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory. In 2007, they found a six-rule Turing machine that broke the record for the longest runtime: The number of steps it took before halting had nearly 3,000 digits. That’s a colossal number by any ordinary measure. But it’s not too big to write down. In 12-point font, those 3,000 digits will just about cover a single sheet of paper.</p>
<aside class="post__aside mb2 relative post__aside--right"><figure class='mb2 mt1 image--shortcode s:mt-0'>
    <div class='relative image mx0'>
        <img width="1500" height="2004" src="https://www.quantamagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/ShawnLigocki-cr.-.webp" class="block fit-x fill-h fill-v is-loaded mxa large-print-img vertical" alt="A man with glasses and a blue beanie" decoding="async" srcset="https://www.quantamagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/ShawnLigocki-cr.-.webp 1500w, https://www.quantamagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/ShawnLigocki-cr.--1287x1720.webp 1287w, https://www.quantamagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/ShawnLigocki-cr.--389x520.webp 389w, https://www.quantamagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/ShawnLigocki-cr.--768x1026.webp 768w, https://www.quantamagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/ShawnLigocki-cr.--1150x1536.webp 1150w" sizes="(max-width: 1500px) 100vw, 1500px" />    </div>
            <figcaption class='image__meta mt1'>
                            <div class='caption wysiwyg h5 theme__anchors--solid fill-h post__aside__caption post__aside__caption--shortcode'>
                    <p>In 2022, Shawn Ligocki discovered a six-rule Turing machine whose runtime has more digits than the number of atoms in the universe.</p>
                </div>
            <div class='attribution theme__anchors--solid wysiwyg pangram h6 mb1 fill-h post__aside__attribution'>
    <p>Kira Treibergs</p>
</div>
        </figcaption>
    </figure>
</aside>
<p>Three years later, a Slovakian undergraduate computer science student named Pavel Kropitz decided to tackle the BB(6) hunt as a senior thesis project. He wrote his own search program and set it up to run in the background on a network of 30 computers in a university lab. After a month he found a machine that ran far longer than the one discovered by the Ligockis — a new “champion,” in the lingo of busy beaver hunters.</p>
<p>“I was lucky, because people in the lab were already complaining about my CPU usage and I had to scale back a bit,” Kropitz wrote in a direct message exchange on the <a href="https://discord.com/invite/3uqtPJA9Uv">Busy Beaver Challenge Discord server</a>. After another month of searching, he broke his own record with a machine whose runtime had over 30,000 digits — enough to fill about 10 pages.</p>
<p>Kropitz’s machine held the BB(6) record for 12 years. Then, in May 2022, Shawn Ligocki started a new job where he had access to a powerful computer cluster, and he decided to try running his old code on newer hardware. Sure enough, he found a new champion that beat Kropitz’s record. The discovery kicked off a flurry of activity. Twice in the span of two weeks, Ligocki announced a <a href="https://groups.google.com/g/busy-beaver-discuss/c/iRHDmAQ5jr8">new</a> <a href="https://groups.google.com/g/busy-beaver-discuss/c/-zjeW6y8ER4">champion</a> on a busy beaver mailing list. Each time, Kropitz beat his record within three days. Ligocki remembers his father marveling at how Kropitz pulled it off.</p>
<p>“He was joking that he imagines Pavel has already solved BB(6),” Ligocki said. “Whenever we find a champion, he just goes and pulls out of his bag one that’s a little bit bigger.”</p>
<p>But the last two machines that Ligocki and Kropitz discovered didn’t run just a bit longer than the reigning champion — their runtimes were on an entirely new level.</p>
<p>To understand numbers this large, we need to go back to the familiar mathematics of addition and multiplication. Start by adding up <em>n</em> copies of a number — that’s just the definition of multiplication by <em>n</em>. If you instead multiply <em>n</em> copies of a number, that’s known as exponentiation. So what happens if you repeatedly exponentiate a number? That process defines a new operation called tetration, denoted by two arrows pointing up.</p>
<p>Tetration gets big fast. $latex 10 \uparrow\uparrow 1$ is just 10. But $latex 10 \uparrow\uparrow 2$ is 10<sup>10</sup>, or 10 billion, and $latex 10 \uparrow\uparrow 3$ is 10 raised to the 10-billionth power: a 1 followed by 10 billion zeros. To write out all the digits you’d need a stack of paper a thousand feet high. At $latex 10 \uparrow\uparrow 4$, you cross a symbolic threshold where it’s no longer a matter of finding enough paper — there are far more digits than atoms in the universe.</p>
</div>
        </div>
    </div>
</section>
</div>
    <figure class='leading-0 w-full my-0 mx-auto flex items-center justify-center flex-col max-w-img-inline py-0 px-16 s:px-0 l:px-16  '>
        <div class='w-full flex justify-center max-w-mod-inline image--module s:flex-col s:m-auto'>
                            <div class='w-auto mr-2 last:mr-0 s:m-0 s:flex s:flex-col flex-1 s:px-5'>
                    <img src="https://www.quantamagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/LargeNumberLadder-cr.SamuelVelasco-Mobile.svg" class="w-full m:hidden l:hidden mb-6 w-full s:mb-4" alt="A graphic depicting how large number are notated" decoding="async" /><img src="https://www.quantamagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/LargeNumberLadder-cr.SamuelVelasco-Desktop.svg" class="mb-6 w-full s:mb-4 s:hidden" alt="A graphic depicting how large number are notated" decoding="async" />                </div>
                        </div>
        <figcaption class='block my-0 mx-auto  w-full'>
    <section class='s:pt-0 s:px-5 s:pb-6 s:w-full-minus-25'>
        <div class='w-full my-0 mx-auto max-w-mod-inline s:mt-4 s:mb-4'>
            <div class='attribution theme__anchors--solid wysiwyg pangram h6 mb1 fill-h '>
    <p>Samuel Velasco/<em>Quanta Magazine</em></p>
</div>
        </div>
    </section>
</figcaption>
    </figure>
<div class='acf-content scale1 mt2'>
    <section class='outer mha js-router-anchors outer--content'>
    <div class='flex-auto mha container--xs '>
                <div class='post__content__section wysiwyg p theme__anchors--underline' data-role='selectable'>
            <div class='post__content wysiwyg p theme__anchors--underline '>
    <p>When Ligocki beat Kropitz’s record for the second time, it was with a six-rule Turing machine that ran for over $latex 10 \uparrow\uparrow 5$ steps before halting. Kropitz countered with a machine that ran for $latex 10 \uparrow\uparrow 15$ steps — that’s a tower of tens 15 stories high. They’d left the familiar world of digits far behind.</p>
<p>“That was the end of an era,” Kropitz wrote over direct message.</p>
<p>It was also the end of an era in another respect. Until then, the busy beaver game had been a competition, and researchers mostly worked alone. Then the Busy Beaver Challenge was formed, ushering in a new age of collaboration.</p>
<h2><strong>A New Class of Crazy</strong></h2>
<p>The Busy Beaver Challenge was founded in 2022 by a computer science graduate student named <a href="https://tristan.st">Tristan Stérin</a> with the express purpose of rigorously proving the true value of BB(5). In summer 2024 the group succeeded, with a key contribution from a mysterious newcomer known only by the pseudonym mxdys.</p>
<p>News of the result <a href="https://www.quantamagazine.org/amateur-mathematicians-find-fifth-busy-beaver-turing-machine-20240702/">appeared in <em>Quanta</em></a>, where <a href="https://katelyndoucette.com/">Katelyn Doucette</a>, an undergraduate computer science student at Virginia Tech, happened to see it. She soon joined the Busy Beaver Challenge community, at first just dropping in to the Discord server from time to time. But in May she made an exciting discovery, and since then she’s become one of the most active contributors to the BB(6) hunt. “I’ve just been kind of hooked,” she said. “It’s such a beautiful set of problems.”</p>
<aside class="post__aside mb2 relative post__aside--right"><figure class='mb2 mt1 image--shortcode s:mt-0'>
    <div class='relative image mx0'>
        <img width="704" height="704" src="https://www.quantamagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/BusyBeaver6Update-crKristinaArmitage-Detail.webp" class="block fit-x fill-h fill-v is-loaded mxa" alt="" decoding="async" srcset="https://www.quantamagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/BusyBeaver6Update-crKristinaArmitage-Detail.webp 704w, https://www.quantamagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/BusyBeaver6Update-crKristinaArmitage-Detail-520x520.webp 520w, https://www.quantamagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/BusyBeaver6Update-crKristinaArmitage-Detail-160x160.webp 160w" sizes="(max-width: 704px) 100vw, 704px" />    </div>
    </figure>
</aside>
<p>In the year since putting the finishing touches on the BB(5) proof, mxdys had steadily chipped away at the BB(6) problem, using sophisticated automated methods to classify all but a few thousand “holdout” machines. Doucette was rooting around in the list of holdouts when she found <a href="https://wiki.bbchallenge.org/wiki/1RB0LF_1RC1RB_1LD0RA_1LB0LE_1RZ0LC_1LA1LF">one that looked especially promising</a>. Analyzing it further with some help from Shawn Ligocki, she discovered that its runtime was second only to that of Kropitz’s reigning champion. What’s more, Doucette’s machine belonged to a class of machines known as <a href="https://www.sligocki.com/2023/02/05/shift-overflow.html">shift overflow counters</a>, which achieve long runtimes using a very different mechanism than Kropitz’s champion.</p>
<p>“It’s exciting to see that these busy beavers have found a new technology,” Ligocki said.</p>
<p>A few other busy beaver hunters had <a href="https://wiki.bbchallenge.org/wiki/1RB3LA4RB0RB2LA_1LB2LA3LA1RA1RZ">previously</a> <a href="https://wiki.bbchallenge.org/wiki/1RB1RC_1LC1RE_1LD0LB_1RE1LC_1LE0RF_1RZ1RA">discovered</a> shift overflow counters that halted after a long time, but Doucette’s discovery made the team suspect that these machines were more plentiful than they’d realized. And if some of the first ones to be studied had come within striking distance of Kropitz’s record, others would likely surpass it. Busy Beaver Challenge contributors rushed to analyze other shift overflow counters, but mxdys got there first. On June 16, they announced the discovery of <a href="https://wiki.bbchallenge.org/wiki/1RB1LC_1LA1RE_0RD0LA_1RZ1LB_1LD0RF_0RD1RB">a new champion</a> that halted after $latex 10 \uparrow\uparrow 10^7$ steps— that is, its runtime is a tower of tens that’s 10 million stories high. Writing this number down as a string of digits is out of the question. But even writing it as a tower of powers gets dicey: In 12-point font, that line of tens would stretch out for about 25 miles.</p>
<p>Kropitz, who saw the news while away on vacation, accepted the loss of his title graciously, writing in the Discord server, “unfortunately, i won’t be performing my 3-day trick this time.” It helped that he had a consolation prize. A month earlier, he’d nabbed the record for the longest-running known seven-rule Turing machine. At least for now, Kropitz is still on the leaderboard.</p>
<h2><strong>Beyond the Biggest</strong></h2>
<p>The new record didn’t last long. A week later, mxdys <a href="https://wiki.bbchallenge.org/wiki/1RB1RA_1RC1RZ_1LD0RF_1RA0LE_0LD1RC_1RA0RE">broke it again</a> with a machine whose runtime is — yet again — on a qualitatively new level. To write it down in its most succinct form, we need to introduce an absurd mathematical operation called pentation, represented by three arrows pointing up. Pentation is repeated tetration — in other words, it bears the same relationship to tetration as tetration does to exponentiation.</p>
<p>The total number of steps that mxdys’ new champion took before halting was greater than $latex 2 \uparrow\uparrow\uparrow 5$, or $latex 2 \uparrow\uparrow (2\uparrow\uparrow(2\uparrow\uparrow(2\uparrow\uparrow2)))$. To unpack this expression, you work outward from the innermost parentheses: $latex 2 \uparrow\uparrow 2$ is 4, and $latex 2 \uparrow\uparrow 4$ is a bit over 65,000. That leaves you with $latex 2 \uparrow\uparrow (2\uparrow\uparrow65,000)$, making the height of the final stack of 2s an incomprehensibly large number. Forget about writing a tower of powers that stretches out for miles or megaparsecs. Even this more compact notation no longer fits in the universe.</p>
</div>
        </div>
    </div>
</section>
</div>
    <figure class='leading-0 w-full my-0 mx-auto flex items-center justify-center flex-col max-w-img-inline py-0 px-16 s:px-0 l:px-16  '>
        <div class='w-full flex justify-center max-w-mod-inline image--module s:flex-col s:m-auto'>
                            <div class='w-auto mr-2 last:mr-0 s:m-0 s:flex s:flex-col flex-1 s:px-5'>
                    <img src="https://www.quantamagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/ANewChampion-cr.KristinaArmitage-Mobile.svg" class="w-full m:hidden l:hidden mb-6 w-full s:mb-4" alt="A graphic depicting the six rules a recently discovered turing machine follows" decoding="async" /><img src="https://www.quantamagazine.org/wp-content/uploads/2025/08/ANewChampion-cr.KristinaArmitage-Desktop.svg" class="mb-6 w-full s:mb-4 s:hidden" alt="A graphic depicting the six rules a recently discovered turing machine follows" decoding="async" />                </div>
                        </div>
        <figcaption class='block my-0 mx-auto  w-full'>
    <section class='s:pt-0 s:px-5 s:pb-6 s:w-full-minus-25'>
        <div class='w-full my-0 mx-auto max-w-mod-inline s:mt-4 s:mb-4'>
            <div class='attribution theme__anchors--solid wysiwyg pangram h6 mb1 fill-h '>
    <p>Kristina Armitage/<em>Quanta Magazine</em></p>
</div>
        </div>
    </section>
</figcaption>
    </figure>
<div class='acf-content scale1 mt2'>
    <section class='outer mha js-router-anchors outer--content'>
    <div class='flex-auto mha container--xs '>
                <div class='post__content__section wysiwyg p theme__anchors--underline' data-role='selectable'>
            <div class='post__content wysiwyg p theme__anchors--underline '>
    <p>This new result is still just a lower limit on BB(6) — the true value could be even higher. Busy beaver hunters don’t expect to have a definitive answer anytime soon. The first sign of trouble was a monstrous six-rule Turing machine that the team has named <a href="https://bbchallenge.org/antihydra">Antihydra</a>, discovered by mxdys last year.</p>
        <div class="related-list">
            <aside class="post__aside mb2 relative hide-on-print post__aside--right">
                <h2 class="mv0 h5 bold uppercase kern">Related:</h2>
                <hr class="mt1 theme__hr-accent">
                <ol class="post__aside__list theme__anchors--none pt05">
                                        <li class="mv075 flex">
                            <h3 class="h5t mt0 mb025">
                                <a class="text-gray-1a1 hover:text-gray-767" href="https://www.quantamagazine.org/amateur-mathematicians-find-fifth-busy-beaver-turing-machine-20240702/">
                                    <span class="' . $span_class . '">With Fifth Busy Beaver, Researchers Approach Computation’s Limits</span>
                                </a>
                            </h3>
                        </li>
                                            <li class="mv075 flex">
                            <h3 class="h5t mt0 mb025">
                                <a class="text-gray-1a1 hover:text-gray-767" href="https://www.quantamagazine.org/how-the-slowest-computer-programs-illuminate-maths-fundamental-limits-20201210/">
                                    <span class="' . $span_class . '">How the Slowest Computer Programs Illuminate Math’s Fundamental Limits</span>
                                </a>
                            </h3>
                        </li>
                                            <li class="mv075 flex">
                            <h3 class="h5t mt0 mb025">
                                <a class="text-gray-1a1 hover:text-gray-767" href="https://www.quantamagazine.org/next-level-chaos-traces-the-true-limit-of-predictability-20250307/">
                                    <span class="' . $span_class . '">‘Next-Level’ Chaos Traces the True Limit of Predictability</span>
                                </a>
                            </h3>
                        </li>
                                    </ol>
            </aside>
        </div>
        
<p>Antihydra almost certainly never halts. But researchers haven’t been able to prove it. And there’s a good reason for that: A busy beaver hunter who goes by Racheline has shown that the question of whether Antihydra halts is closely related to a famous unsolved problem in mathematics called the <a href="https://www.quantamagazine.org/mathematician-proves-huge-result-on-dangerous-problem-20191211/">Collatz conjecture</a>. Since then, the team has discovered many other six-rule machines with similar characteristics. Slaying the Antihydra and its brethren will require conceptual breakthroughs in pure mathematics.</p>
<p>But to avid busy beaver hunters, that’s no reason to be discouraged. There are still thousands of six-rule Turing machines to explore, each with its own rich behavior.</p>
<p>“For me, the most valid reason to do math is because it’s fun. It is art,” Racheline wrote in a Discord direct message. “There will always be something new to do.”</p>
</div>

    </div>
</section>

1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThis weekend at the YC Agents hackathon, we asked ourselves: \u003cem\u003ewhat’s the weirdest way we could use a coding agent?\u003c/em\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eOur answer: run Claude Code headlessly in a loop forever and see what happens.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eTurns out, what happens is: you wake up to 1,000+ commits, six ported codebases, and a wonky little tool we’re calling \u003ca href=\"https://github.com/repomirrorhq/repomirror\"\u003eRepoMirror\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch3 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003eHow We Got Here\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ca id=\"user-content-how-we-got-here\" class=\"anchor\" aria-label=\"Permalink: How We Got Here\" href=\"#how-we-got-here\"\u003e\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eWe recently stumbled upon a technique promoted by \u003ca href=\"https://ghuntley.com/ralph/\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eGeoff Huntley\u003c/a\u003e, to run a coding agent in a while loop:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"while :; do cat prompt.md | amp; done\"\u003e\u003cpre class=\"notranslate\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003ewhile :; do cat prompt.md | amp; done\n\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eOne of our team members, Simon, is the creator of assistant-ui, a React library for building AI interfaces in React. He gets a lot of requests to add Vue.js support, and he wondered if the approach would work for porting assistant-ui to Vue.js.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch3 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003eHow It Works\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ca id=\"user-content-how-it-works\" class=\"anchor\" aria-label=\"Permalink: How It Works\" href=\"#how-it-works\"\u003e\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eBasically what we ended up doing sounds really dumb, but it works surprisingly well - we used Claude Code for the loop:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"while :; do cat prompt.md | claude -p --dangerously-skip-permissions; done\"\u003e\u003cpre class=\"notranslate\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003ewhile :; do cat prompt.md | claude -p --dangerously-skip-permissions; done\n\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThe prompt was simple:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"Your job is to port assistant-ui-react monorepo (for react) to assistant-ui-vue (for vue) and maintain the repository.\n\nYou have access to the current assistant-ui-react repository as well as the assistant-ui-vue repository.\n\nMake a commit and push your changes after every single file edit.\n\nUse the assistant-ui-vue/.agent/ directory as a scratchpad for your work. Store long term plans and todo lists there.\n\nThe original project was mostly tested by manually running the code. When porting, you will need to write end to end and unit tests for the project. But make sure to spend most of your time on the actual porting, not on the testing. A good heuristic is to spend 80% of your time on the actual porting, and 20% on the\ntesting.\"\u003e\u003cpre class=\"notranslate\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003eYour job is to port assistant-ui-react monorepo (for react) to assistant-ui-vue (for vue) and maintain the repository.\n\nYou have access to the current assistant-ui-react repository as well as the assistant-ui-vue repository.\n\nMake a commit and push your changes after every single file edit.\n\nUse the assistant-ui-vue/.agent/ directory as a scratchpad for your work. Store long term plans and todo lists there.\n\nThe original project was mostly tested by manually running the code. When porting, you will need to write end to end and unit tests for the project. But make sure to spend most of your time on the actual porting, not on the testing. A good heuristic is to spend 80% of your time on the actual porting, and 20% on the\ntesting.\n\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" decided to see if Ralph could port \u003ca href=\"https://github.com/browser-use/browser-use\"\u003eBrowser Use\u003c/a\u003e, a YC-backed web agent tool, from Python to TypeScript.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eWe kicked off the loop with a simple prompt:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"Your job is to port browser-use monorepo (Python) to better-use (Typescript) and maintain the repository.\n\nMake a commit and push your changes after every single file edit.\n\nKeep track of your current status in browser-use-ts/agent/TODO.md\"\u003e\u003cpre class=\"notranslate\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003eYour job is to port browser-use monorepo code. We think he liked it.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\" href=\"/repomirrorhq/repomirror/blob/main/assets/gregor.png\"\u003e\u003cimg src=\"/repomirrorhq/repomirror/raw/main/assets/gregor.png\" alt=\"Gregor and Simon smiling at laptop\" style=\"max-width: 100%;\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch3 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003eWe Did Some More\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ca id=\"user-content-we-did-some-more\" class=\"anchor\" aria-label=\"Permalink: We Did Some More\" href=\"#we-did-some-more\"\u003e\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eSince we were spinning up a few loops anyways, we decided to port a few more software projects to see what came out.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eThe Vercel AI SDK is in TypeScript... but what if you could use it in Python? Yeah... \u003ca href=\"https://github.com/repomirrorhq/ai-sdk-python\"\u003eit kind of worked\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\" href=\"/repomirrorhq/repomirror/blob/main/assets/ai-sdk-fastapi.png\"\u003e\u003cimg src=\"/repomirrorhq/repomirror/raw/main/assets/ai-sdk-fastapi.png\" alt=\"AI SDK FastAPI Adapters\" style=\"max-width: 100%;\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIf you've ever struggled with some of the deeply-nested type constructors in the AI SDK, well, now you can struggle with them in Python too.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eWe also tried a few specs-to-code loops - recreating \u003ca href=\"https://www.convex.dev\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eConvex\u003c/a\u003e and \u003ca href=\"https://dedalus.dev\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eDedalus\u003c/a\u003e from their docs' llms-full.txt. Here's a first pass at \u003ca href=\"https://github.com/repomirrorhq/open-dedalus\"\u003eOpenDedalus\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\" href=\"/repomirrorhq/repomirror/blob/main/assets/open-dedalus.png\"\u003e\u003cimg src=\"/repomirrorhq/repomirror/raw/main/assets/open-dedalus.png\" alt=\"Image of open-dedalus README\" style=\"max-width: 100%;\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch3 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003eWhat We Learned\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ca id=\"user-content-what-we-learned\" class=\"anchor\" aria-label=\"Permalink: What We Learned\" href=\"#what-we-learned\"\u003e\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eEarly Stopping\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eWhen starting the agents, we had a lot of questions. Will the agent write tests? Will it get stuck in an infinite loop and drift into random unrelated features?\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eWe were pleasantly surprised to find that the agent wrote tests, kept to its original instructions, never got stuck, kept scope under control and mostly declared the port 'done'.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eAfter finishing the port, most of the agents settled for writing extra tests or continuously updating agent/TODO.md to clarify how \"done\" they were. In one instance, the agent actually used \u003ccode\u003epkill\u003c/code\u003e \u003ca href=\"https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UOLBTRazZpM\" rel=\"nofollow\"\u003eto terminate itself\u003c/a\u003e after realizing it was stuck in an infinite loop.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ca target=\"_blank\" rel=\"noopener noreferrer\" href=\"/repomirrorhq/repomirror/blob/main/assets/pkill.png\"\u003e\u003cimg src=\"/repomirrorhq/repomirror/raw/main/assets/pkill.png\" alt=\"Agent stopping its own process\" style=\"max-width: 100%;\"\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eOverachieving\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eAnother cool emergent behavior (as is common with LLMs) - After finishing the initial port, our AI SDK Python agent started adding extra features such as an integration for Flask and FastAPI (something that has no counterpart in the AI SDK JS version), as well as support for schema validators via Pydantic, Marshmallow, JSONSchema, etc.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eKeep the Prompt Simple\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eOverall we found that less is more - a simple prompt is better than a complex one. You want to focus on the engine, not the scaffolding. Different members of our team kicking off different projects played around with instructions and ordering. You can view the actual prompts we used in the \u003ca href=\"/repomirrorhq/repomirror/blob/main/prompts\"\u003eprompts folder\u003c/a\u003e.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eAt one point we tried “improving” the prompt with Claude’s help. It ballooned to 1,500 words. The agent immediately got slower and dumber. We went back to 103 words and it was back on track.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003cstrong\u003eThis is not perfect\u003c/strong\u003e\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eFor both \u003ca href=\"https://github.com/repomirrorhq/better-use\"\u003ebetter-use\u003c/a\u003e and \u003ca href=\"https://github.com/repomirrorhq/ai-sdk-python\"\u003eai-sdk-python\u003c/a\u003e, the headless agent didn't always deliver perfect working code. We ended up going in and updating the prompts incrementally or working with Claude Code interactively to get things from 90% to 100%.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eAnd as much as Claude may \u003ca href=\"https://github.com/repomirrorhq/better-use/blob/master/agent/TODO.md\"\u003eclaim that things are 100% perfectly implemented\u003c/a\u003e, there are a few browser-use demos from the Python project that don't work yet in TypeScript.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch3 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003eNumbers\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ca id=\"user-content-numbers\" class=\"anchor\" aria-label=\"Permalink: Numbers\" href=\"#numbers\"\u003e\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eWe spent a little less than $800 on inference for the project. Overall the agents made ~1100 commits across all software projects. Each Sonnet agent costs about $10.50/hour to run overnight.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"markdown-heading\" dir=\"auto\"\u003e\u003ch3 tabindex=\"-1\" class=\"heading-element\" dir=\"auto\"\u003eWhat We Built Around It\u003c/h3\u003e\u003ca id=\"user-content-what-we-built-around-it\" class=\"anchor\" aria-label=\"Permalink: What We Built Around It\" href=\"#what-we-built-around-it\"\u003e\u003csvg class=\"octicon octicon-link\" viewBox=\"0 0 16 16\" version=\"1.1\" width=\"16\" height=\"16\" aria-hidden=\"true\"\u003e\u003cpath d=\"m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eAs we went about bootstrapping so many of these, we put together a simple tool to help set up a source/target repo pair for this sync work. (and yeah, \u003ca href=\"https://github.com/repomirrorhq/repomirror/blob/main/prompt.md\"\u003ewe also built that with Ralph\u003c/a\u003e)\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"npx repomirror init \\\n    --source-dir ./browser-use \\\n    --target-dir ./browser-use-zig \\\n    --instructions \u0026quot;convert browser use to Zig\u0026quot;\"\u003e\u003cpre class=\"notranslate\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003enpx repomirror init \\\n    --source-dir ./browser-use \\\n    --target-dir ./browser-use-zig \\\n    --instructions \"convert browser use to Zig\"\n\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eInstructions can be anything like \"convert from React to Vue\" or \"change from gRPC to REST using OpenAPI spec codegen\".\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIt's not perfectly architected, and it's a little hacky. But it was enough to hack things together, and it's designed similar to shadcn's \"open-box\" approach where it generates scripts/prompts that you are welcome to modify after the \u003ccode\u003einit\u003c/code\u003e phase.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eAfter the init phase, you'll have:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"snippet-clipboard-content notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\".repomirror/\n   - prompt.md\n   - sync.sh\n   - ralph.sh\"\u003e\u003cpre class=\"notranslate\"\u003e\u003ccode\u003e.repomirror/\n   - prompt.md\n   - sync.sh\n   - ralph.sh\n\u003c/code\u003e\u003c/pre\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eWhen you've checked out the prompt and you're ready to test it, you can run \u003ccode\u003enpx repomirror sync\u003c/code\u003e to do a single iteration of the loop, and you can run \u003ccode\u003enpx repomirror sync-forever\u003c/code\u003e to kick off the Ralph infinite loop:\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdetails open=\"\" class=\"details-reset border rounded-2\"\u003e\n  \u003csummary class=\"px-3 py-2\"\u003e\n best, up to 256 colors is supported).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIt uses \u003cstrong\u003e\"Prediction by Partial Matching, Order-2\"\u003c/strong\u003e compression, which is able to compress packed-palette-indices smaller than GIF, PNG, and QOI, while sacrificing a bit of time.\nIt's 2-10x slower than GIF/PNG/QOI (depending on the image), but often compresses the image 20-50% smaller than GIF/PNG (and multiple-times smaller than QOI).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003eIf you care about compressed image size, this is for you. 2.83Z\"\u003e\u003c/path\u003e\u003c/svg\u003e\u003c/a\u003e\u003c/div\u003e\n\u003cp dir=\"auto\"\u003ePEP is designed for games too, so the compression outputs a structure that has useful elements. The PEP.data pointer ONLY contains the bytes for the pixels.\nThis library doesn't have a BMP loader, so this is specifically designed for setups where the color bytes already exist.\nYou just feed it into pep_compress() with the correct in_format of the bytes, and then you're able to use it however you like! Often you just use pep_save() after compressing, and then pep_load() + pep_decompress() to access the image data.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cdiv class=\"highlight highlight-source-c notranslate position-relative overflow-auto\" dir=\"auto\" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content=\"/*\npep_compress() parameters:\n\tuint32_t*  PIXEL_BYTES = raw RGBA/BGRA pixels\n\tuint16_t   WIDTH       = width of the image\n\tuint16_t   HEIGHT      = height of the image\n\tpep_format IN_FORMAT   = channel-order of PIXEL_BYTES, either pep_rgba or pep_bgra\n\tpep_format OUT_FORMAT  = channel-order of the new PEP, either pep_rgba or pep_bgra\nreturns:\n\ta pep struct\n*/\npep p = pep_compress( PIXEL_BYTES, WIDTH, HEIGHT, IN_FORMAT, OUT_FORMAT );\n\n/*\npep_decompress() parameters:\n\tpep*       IN_PEP     = pep struct-pointer to decompress\n\tpep_format OUT_FORMAT = channel-order of the new pixels, either pep_rgba or pep_bgra\nreturns:\n\ta uint32_t* with the uncompressed pixel data\n*/\nuint32_t* pixels = pep_decompress( IN_PEP, OUT_FORMAT );\n\n/*\npep_free() parameters:\n\tpep* IN_PEP = pep struct-pointer to free\nnote:\n\tfrees the internal bytes buffer and resets bytes_size to 0\n*/\npep_free( IN_PEP );\n\n/*\npep_serialize() parameters:\n\tpep*      IN_PEP   = pep struct-pointer to serialize\n\tuint32_t* OUT_SIZE = pointer to store the resulting byte array size\nreturns:\n\ta uint8_t* byte array containing the serialized pep data\nnote:\n\tcaller must free() the returned byte array when done\n*/\nuint8_t* bytes = pep_serialize( IN_PEP, OUT_SIZE );\n\n/*\npep_deserialize() parameters:\n\tuint8_t* IN_BYTES = byte array containing serialized pep data\nreturns:\n\ta pep struct reconstructed from the byte array\n*/\npep p = pep_deserialize( IN_BYTES );\n\n/*\npep_save() parameters:\n\tpep*  IN_PEP    = pep struct-pointer to save\n\tchar* FILE_PATH = path to save the .pep file (e.g. \u0026quot;image.pep\u0026quot;)\nreturns:\n\tuint8_t - 1 on success, 0 on failure\n*/\nuint8_t success = pep_save( IN_PEP, FILE_PATH );\n\n/*\npep_load() parameters:\n\tchar* FILE_PATH = path to the .pep file to load (e.g. \u0026quot;image.pep\u0026quot;)\nreturns:\n\ta pep struct loaded from the file\nnote:\n\treturns an empty pep struct on failure\n*/\npep p = pep_load( FILE_PATH );\"\u003e\u003cpre\u003e\u003cspan   <a target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" href="https://private-user-images.githubusercontent.com/38831818/481422405-9b8922e7-cc9f-45e8-8ec7-206d92d50e8d.png?jwt=eyJ0eXAiOiJKV1QiLCJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiJ9..z9Rg2MOgaYMGGcFvRoD53zgtoeFtDwOgp0KyLh6wcJU"><img width="725" height="383" alt="pep_logo" src="https://private-user-images.githubusercontent.com/38831818/481422405-9b8922e7-cc9f-45e8-8ec7-206d92d50e8d.png?jwt=eyJ0eXAiOiJKV1QiLCJhbGciOiJIUzI1NiJ9..z9Rg2MOgaYMGGcFvRoD53zgtoeFtDwOgp0KyLh6wcJU" style="max-width: 100%; height: auto; max-height: 383px;"></a>
</p>
<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h1 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Prediction-Encoded Pixels</h1><a id="user-content-prediction-encoded-pixels" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: Prediction-Encoded Pixels" href="#prediction-encoded-pixels"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div>
<p dir="auto">This format is specifically designed to be for low-color pixel art (<=16 colors works best, up to 256 colors is supported).</p>
<p dir="auto">It uses <strong>"Prediction by Partial Matching, Order-2"</strong> compression, which is able to compress packed-palette-indices smaller than GIF, PNG, and QOI, while sacrificing a bit of time.
It's 2-10x slower than GIF/PNG/QOI (depending on the image), but often compresses the image 20-50% smaller than GIF/PNG (and multiple-times smaller than QOI).</p>
<p dir="auto">If you care about compressed image size, this is for you. It's somewhere between GIF and WEBP (.webp can compress better at times, but it's painfully slow).</p>
<hr>
<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h3 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto"><em>( this is currently in the EXPERIMENTAL phase! )</em></h3><a id="user-content--this-is-currently-in-the-experimental-phase-" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: ( this is currently in the EXPERIMENTAL phase! )" href="#-this-is-currently-in-the-experimental-phase-"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div>
<hr>
<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h2 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">How to use it:</h2><a id="user-content-how-to-use-it" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: How to use it:" href="#how-to-use-it"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div>

<div class="markdown-heading" dir="auto"><h2 tabindex="-1" class="heading-element" dir="auto">Mini-documentation:</h2><a id="user-content-mini-documentation" class="anchor" aria-label="Permalink: Mini-documentation:" href="#mini-documentation"><svg class="octicon octicon-link" viewBox="0 0 16 16" version="1.1" width="16" height="16" aria-hidden="true"><path d="m7.775 3.275 1.25-1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1 4.95 4.95l-2.5 2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1-4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1 .018-1.042.751.751 0 0 1 1.042-.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l2.5-2.5a2.002 2.002 0 0 0-2.83-2.83l-1.25 1.25a.751.751 0 0 1-1.042-.018.751.751 0 0 1-.018-1.042Zm-4.69 9.64a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 2.83 0l1.25-1.25a.751.751 0 0 1 1.042.018.751.751 0 0 1 .018 1.042l-1.25 1.25a3.5 3.5 0 1 1-4.95-4.95l2.5-2.5a3.5 3.5 0 0 1 4.95 0 .751.751 0 0 1-.018 1.042.751.751 0 0 1-1.042.018 1.998 1.998 0 0 0-2.83 0l-2.5 2.5a1.998 1.998 0 0 0 0 2.83Z"></path></svg></a></div>
<p dir="auto">PEP is designed for games too, so the compression outputs a structure that has useful elements. The PEP.data pointer ONLY contains the bytes for the pixels.
This library doesn't have a BMP loader, so this is specifically designed for setups where the color bytes already exist.
You just feed it into pep_compress() with the correct in_format of the bytes, and then you're able to use it however you like! Often you just use pep_save() after compressing, and then pep_load() + pep_decompress() to access the image data.</p>
<div class="highlight highlight-source-c notranslate position-relative overflow-auto" dir="auto" data-snippet-clipboard-copy-content="/*
pep_compress() parameters:
	uint32_t*  PIXEL_BYTES = raw RGBA/BGRA pixels
	uint16_t   WIDTH       = width of the image
	uint16_t   HEIGHT      = height of the image
	pep_format IN_FORMAT   = channel-order of PIXEL_BYTES, either pep_rgba or pep_bgra
	pep_format OUT_FORMAT  = channel-order of the new PEP, either pep_rgba or pep_bgra
returns:
	a pep struct
*/
pep p = pep_compress( PIXEL_BYTES, WIDTH, HEIGHT, IN_FORMAT, OUT_FORMAT );

/*
pep_decompress() parameters:
	pep*       IN_PEP     = pep struct-pointer to decompress
	pep_format OUT_FORMAT = channel-order of the new pixels, either pep_rgba or pep_bgra
returns:
	a uint32_t* with the uncompressed pixel data
*/
uint32_t* pixels = pep_decompress( IN_PEP, OUT_FORMAT );

/*
pep_free() parameters:
	pep* IN_PEP = pep struct-pointer to free
note:
	frees the internal bytes buffer and resets bytes_size to 0
*/
pep_free( IN_PEP );

/*
pep_serialize() parameters:
	pep*      IN_PEP   = pep struct-pointer to serialize
	uint32_t* OUT_SIZE = pointer to store the resulting byte array size
returns:
	a uint8_t* byte array containing the serialized pep data
note:
	caller must free() the returned byte array when done
*/
uint8_t* bytes = pep_serialize( IN_PEP, OUT_SIZE );

/*
pep_deserialize() parameters:
	uint8_t* IN_BYTES = byte array containing serialized pep data
returns:
	a pep struct reconstructed from the byte array
*/
pep p = pep_deserialize( IN_BYTES );

/*
pep_save() parameters:
	pep*  IN_PEP    = pep struct-pointer to save
	char* FILE_PATH = path to save the .pep file (e.g. "image.pep")
returns:
	uint8_t - 1 on success, 0 on failure
*/
uint8_t success = pep_save( IN_PEP, FILE_PATH );

/*
pep_load() parameters:
	char* FILE_PATH = path to the .pep file to load (e.g. "image.pep")
returns:
	a pep struct loaded from the file
note:
	returns an empty pep struct on failure
*/
pep p = pep_load( FILE_PATH );"><pre><span class="pl-c">/*</span>
<span class="pl-c">pep_compress() parameters:</span>
<span class="pl-c">	uint32_t*  PIXEL_BYTES = raw RGBA/BGRA pixels</span>
<span class="pl-c">	uint16_t   WIDTH       = width of the image</span>
<span class="pl-c">	uint16_t   HEIGHT      = height of the image</span>
<span class="pl-c">	pep_format IN_FORMAT   = channel-order of PIXEL_BYTES, either pep_rgba or pep_bgra</span>
<span class="pl-c">	pep_format OUT_FORMAT  = channel-order of the new PEP, either pep_rgba or pep_bgra</span>
<span class="pl-c">returns:</span>
<span class="pl-c">	a pep struct</span>
<span class="pl-c">*/</span>
<span class="pl-smi">pep</span> <span class="pl-s1">p</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-en">pep_compress</span>( <span class="pl-c1">PIXEL_BYTES</span>, <span class="pl-c1">WIDTH</span>, <span class="pl-c1">HEIGHT</span>, <span class="pl-c1">IN_FORMAT</span>, <span class="pl-c1">OUT_FORMAT</span> );

<span class="pl-c">/*</span>

<span class="pl-c">returns:</span>
<span class="pl-c">	a uint32_t* with the uncompressed pixel data</span>
<span class="pl-c">*/</span>
<span class="pl-smi">uint32_t</span><span class="pl-c1">*</span> <span class="pl-s1">pixels</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-en">pep_decompress</span>( <span class="pl-c1">IN_PEP</span>, <span class="pl-c1">OUT_FORMAT</span> );

<span class="pl-c">/*</span>
<span class="pl-c">pep_free() parameters:</span>
<span class="pl-c">	pep* IN_PEP = pep struct-pointer to free</span>
<span class="pl-c">note:</span>

<span class="pl-c">/*</span>

<span class="pl-c">	pep*      IN_PEP   = pep struct-pointer to serialize</span>

<span class="pl-c">returns:</span>
<span class="pl-c">	a uint8_t* byte array containing the serialized pep data</span>
<span class="pl-c">note:</span>
<span class="pl-c">	caller must free() the returned byte array when done</span>
<span class="pl-c">*/</span>
<span class="pl-smi">uint8_t</span><span class="pl-c1">*</span> <span class="pl-s1">bytes</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-en">pep_serialize</span>( <span class="pl-c1">IN_PEP</span>, <span class="pl-c1">OUT_SIZE</span> );

<span class="pl-c">/*</span>
<span class="pl-c">pep_deserialize() parameters:</span>
<span class="pl-c">	uint8_t* IN_BYTES = byte array containing serialized pep data</span>
<span class="pl-c">returns:</span>
<span class="pl-c">	a pep struct reconstructed from the byte array</span>
<span class="pl-c">*/</span>
<span class="pl-smi">pep</span> <span class="pl-s1">p</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-en">pep_deserialize</span>( <span class="pl-c1">IN_BYTES</span> );

<span class="pl-c">/*</span>
<span class="pl-c">pep_save() parameters:</span>
<span class="pl-c">	pep*  IN_PEP    = pep struct-pointer to save</span>
<span class="pl-c">	char* FILE_PATH = path to save the .pep file (e.g. "image.pep")</span>
<span class="pl-c">returns:</span>
<span class="pl-c">	uint8_t - 1 on success, 0 on failure</span>
<span class="pl-c">*/</span>
<span class="pl-smi">uint8_t</span> <span class="pl-s1">success</span> <span class="pl-c1">=</span> <span class="pl-en">pep_save</span>( <span class="pl-c1">IN_PEP</span>, <span class="pl-c1">FILE_PATH</span> );

<span class="pl-c">/*</span>

<span class="pl-c">note:</span>
